revision.comment: close up space before ref numeral
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Triquetrum (disambiguation)}} :''The term "triquetra" has formerly also been used to refer to the triple spiral design discussed under ''[[triskelion]]''.'' {{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Refimprove|date=March 2010}} [[File:Coa_Illustration_Cross_Triquetra.svg|right|thumb|Interlaced triquetra which is a [[trefoil knot]]]] The '''triquetra''' ({{IPAc-en|t|r|aɪ|ˈ|k|w|ɛ|t|r|ə}}; from the Latin adjective ''triquetrus'' "three-cornered") is a triangular figure composed of three interlaced arcs, or (equivalently) three overlapping ''[[Vesica piscis|vesicae piscis]]'' lens shapes.
It is used as an ornamental design in architecture, and in medieval manuscript illumination (particularly in the [[Insular illumination|Insular tradition]]). Its depiction as interlaced is common in Insular ornaments from about the 7th century. In this interpretation, the triquetra represents the topologically [[trefoil knot|simplest possible knot]].
==History==
===Iron Age===
The term ''triquetra'' in archaeology is used of any figure consisting of three arcs, including [[pinwheel]] design of the type of the [[triskeles]]. Such symbols become frequent from about the 4th century BC ornamented ceramics of Anatolia and Persia, and it appears on early [[Lycia]]n coins.<ref>John Burley Waring, ''Ceramic Art in Remote Ages'' (1874), [https://books.google.ch/books?id=z7NFAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA84 84f.]</ref>
The triquetra is found on [[runestone]]s in Northern Europe and on early [[Germanic peoples|Germanic]] coins.{{cn|date=March 2020}} It bears a resemblance to the so-called ''[[valknut]]'', a design of three interlacing triangles, found in the same context.
===Insular art=== The triquetra is often found in [[insular art]], most notably metal work and in [[illuminated manuscript]]s like the ''[[Book of Kells]]''. It is a "minor though recurring theme" in the secondary phase of Anglo-Saxon [[sceatta]] production (c. 710–760).<ref name=Abramson1>Tony Abramson (ed.), ''Two Decades of Discovery'' Studies in Medieval Coinage 1, Boydell Press (2008), [https://books.google.ch/books?id=G7p69a0Rk24C&pg=PA1 p. 1].</ref> It is found in similar artwork on early Christian [[High cross|High Cross]]es and slabs. An example from early medieval stonework is the Anglo-Saxon frith stool at Hexham Abbey.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ascorpus.ac.uk/catvol1.php?pageNum_urls=284&totalRows_urls=532|title=The Corpus of Anglo-Saxon Stone Sculpture|website=www.ascorpus.ac.uk|access-date=2019-07-16}}</ref>
The symbol has been interpreted as representing the Christian [[Trinity]], especially since the Celtic revival of the 19th century. The original intention by the early medieval artists is unknown and experts warn against over-interpretation.<ref name=Abramson1/>
===Buddhist tradition=== The triquetra has been a known symbol in Japan called ''Musubi Mitsugashiwa''. Being one of the forms of the [[Aryan]] [[Ikshvaku dynasty|Iakšaku dynasty]] signs, it reached Japan with the dynasty's [[Kāśyapīya]] spreading technology and [[Buddhism]] via [[Kingdom of Khotan]], [[Chinese Buddhism|China]] and [[Korean Buddhism|Korea]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}}
==Modern use==
The triquetra is often used artistically as a design element when [[Celtic knotwork]] is used, especially in association with the modern [[Celtic Nations]]. The triquetra, also known as a "trinity knot", is often found as a design element is popular Irish jewelry such as [[Claddagh ring|claddaghs]] and other wedding or engagement rings.<ref>McMahon, Seán (1999). ''Story of the Claddagh Ring''. Mercier Press. {{ISBN|9781856351898}}.</ref>{{page missing|date=October 2018}}
[[Celtic neopaganism|Celtic pagans]] or [[Neopaganism|neopagans]] who are not of a Celtic cultural orientation, may use the triquetra to symbolise a variety of concepts and mythological figures. Due to its presence in insular Celtic art, [[Celtic Reconstructionist Paganism|Celtic Reconstructionists]] use the triquetra either to represent one of the various triplicities in their cosmology and theology (such as the tripartite division of the world into the realms of Land, Sea and Sky),<ref name="Mac Mathúna">Mac Mathúna, Liam (1999) [http://www.celt.dias.ie/publications/celtica/c23/c23-174.pdf "Irish Perceptions of the Cosmos"] ''Celtica'' vol. 23 (1999), pp.174–187</ref> or as a symbol of one of the specific Celtic [[Triple deity|triple goddesses]], for example the battle goddess, [[The Morrígan]]. The symbol is also sometimes used by Wiccans and some [[New Age]]rs to symbolise the [[Triple Goddess (Neopaganism)|Triple Goddess]], or as a protective symbol.<ref name="scott-cunningham">{{Citation |last=Cunningham |first=Scott |authorlink=Scott Cunningham |title=Wicca: A Guide to the Solitary Practitioner |year=2004 |origyear=1988 |publisher=Llewellyn |location=Woodbury, MN, U.S.A. |isbn=978-0-87542-118-6 |page=191 |chapter=Rune Magic}}.</ref>
The symbol is used as the logo for the 1998–2006 TV series ''[[Charmed]]'' and its [[Charmed (2018 TV series)|2018 reboot series]].
In the TV series ''[[The Walking Dead (TV series)|The Walking Dead]]'' (2010), [[Michonne]]'s [[katana]] features a triquetra, chosen for its meaning as a "triple goddess symbol".<ref name=EW>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.ew.com/gallery/walking-dead-14-props-and-stories-behind-em/670478_michonnes-katana | title=Michonne's Katana | magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] | date=17 November 2013 | accessdate=30 October 2016 | author=Ross, Dalton |author2=Snetiker, Marc}}</ref><ref name=USAtoday>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2014/10/08/walkers-weapons-bees-at-amc-the-walking-dead/16886945/ | title=<nowiki>'</nowiki>The Walking Dead,' up close and personal | newspaper=[[USA Today]] | date=12 October 2014 | accessdate=30 October 2016 | last=Keveney | first=Bill | quote=We put a trinity on there – mind, body, soul. That's important to who Michonne (Danai Gurira) is. We put some squares around it. And (executive producer) Robert Kirkman wanted a symbol that was like the biohazard symbol … so we put a triple goddess on there, which looks exactly like it.}}</ref>
==Gallery == <gallery> File:Trikvetra.JPG|Triquetra on one of the [[Funbo Runestones]] (11th century), located in the park of [[Uppsala University]]. File:Trikvetra-closeup.JPG|Close-up of a triquetra on one of the [[Funbo Runestones]]. File:Triquetra-Münze 05.png|Interlaced triquetra on a Norwegian penny minted under [[Harald Hardrada]] (r. 1047-1066) File:Triquetra-Münze 03.png|Norwegian penny minted under Harald Hardrada (r. 1047-1066) File:Cruz_de_Santa_Susana.JPG|Four triquetras forming a "[[Carolingian cross]]" in the church of Santa Susanna in [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] (11th/12th century?). </gallery>
;Variant forms <gallery> File:Triquetra-Vesica.svg|Triquetra composed exactly of three overlapping [[Vesica piscis]] symbols. File:Triquetra-Double.svg|An interlaced double triquetra. File:Triquetra-tightly-knotted.svg|Tightly-knotted form of triquetra. File:Triquetra-circle-interlaced.svg|Triquetra interlaced with circle as Christian Trinitarian symbol (a "Trinity knot"). File:Triquetra-Interlaced-Triangle-Circle.svg|Triquetra in blue as part of an interlaced Christian Trinitarian decorative symbol. File:Vodicka_triquetra1.svg|Interlaced triquetra in the style of the Funbo Runestone File:Triquetra-Cross.svg|The ''cross of triquetras'', or "[[Carolingian cross]]". File:Triquetra-Cross-alternate.svg|Cross composed of four interlaced triquetras. File:Celtic-Cross-Vodicka-decorative-triquetras-red.svg|[[Celtic cross]] with triquetras. </gallery>
==Literature== * [[Hallvard Trætteberg|H. Trætteberg]], E. Moltke, I. Lindeberg, "Triquetra" in: ''[[Kulturhistorisk leksikon for nordisk middelalder]],'' vol. 18 (1982), p. 634–6356. * Martin Blindheim: ''Graffiti in Norwegian stave churches c. 1150 – c. 1''350, Oslo 1985, i.a. p. 44–45
